musicalLanguage.description: The musical heart of Amelie (2001). Tiersen built this piece from repeating arpeggiated patterns that cycle through Em, C, G, and D — simple chords that, through repetition and gradual layering, create an overwhelming sense of bittersweet nostalgia. It sounds harder than it is, which makes it a perfect intermediate piece.
musicalLanguage.structure: A (right hand melody over arpeggios) - B (fuller, both hands arpeggiated) - A return - Coda
keyMoments: The opening right-hand arpeggio figure: the Em pattern that defines the whole piece
The left hand entry: when the piece fills out and the emotion deepens
The climactic section: both hands moving in parallel arpeggios at full intensity
teachingGoals: Arpeggiated accompaniment patterns across chord changes
Building intensity through dynamics, not complexity
Hand independence — different arpeggio patterns in each hand
Pedal technique for sustaining arpeggios without muddiness
styleTips: Keep the arpeggios absolutely even — mechanical precision creates the hypnotic effect
Build dynamics gradually across sections, not within phrases
The sustain pedal is critical — change it cleanly on each chord change
Don't rush — the tempo should feel unhurried, like a memory unfolding
